p: Xanthium strumarium detrimentally influences livestock production as the animals eating the young plants of species may be poisoned. The young plants of the species are attractive and eaten by the pasture animals. Carboxyatractyloside, a poisoning compound is present in the leaves of young plants of the species, whereas it is not found in older plants [ 21, 22]. The detrimental impacts of the species on grazing animals have been reported from Australia, where it is frequently noted in pastures [ 21, 23]. Nonetheless, ‘burrs’ of the species are attached to legs, tails and manes; thus, causing discomfort to the animals.
